article:
J. Robert Oppenheimer

Julius Robert Oppenheimer was a renowned American theoretical physicist and director of the Manhattan Project, the secret research and development project that produced the atomic bomb during World War II. He is often referred to as the "father of the atomic bomb."

# Early life

## Childhood and education

Oppenheimer was born on April 22, 1904, in New York City, to Ella and Julius Oppenheimer, a textile importer. He was the first of two children, and his family was of Jewish descent. Oppenheimer's early life was marked by a fascination with science and mathematics, and he was particularly drawn to chemistry and physics. He attended the Ethical Culture School in New York City, where he excelled academically and developed a passion for learning.

## Studies in Europe

In 1921, Oppenheimer traveled to England to study at Cambridge University, where he was accepted at Christ's College. However, due to poor health, he was forced to return to the United States and continued his studies at Harvard University. In 1924, Oppenheimer returned to Europe, this time to study at the University of Göttingen in Germany, where he earned his Ph.D. in physics in 1927. During his time in Göttingen, Oppenheimer worked under the supervision of Max Born and developed a deep understanding of quantum mechanics.

# Early career

## Teaching

Oppenheimer's academic career began in 1929, when he was appointed as a lecturer in physics at the University of California, Berkeley. In 1930, he moved to the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), where he became an assistant professor of physics. During this period, Oppenheimer established himself as a leading expert in theoretical physics, and his research focused on quantum mechanics and relativity.

## Scientific work

Oppenheimer's scientific contributions during the 1930s were significant, and he published numerous papers on topics such as quantum field theory, nuclear physics, and cosmology. He was also a gifted teacher and mentor, and his students included many future leaders in physics, such as Enrico Fermi and Ernest Lawrence.

# Private and political life

## Politics

Oppenheimer's interest in politics began in the 1930s, and he was drawn to left-wing causes, including communism and socialism. He was a member of the American Communist Party and was involved in various political organizations, including the American Civil Liberties Union. Oppenheimer's politics were shaped by his experiences during the Great Depression and his concern about social and economic inequality.

## Relationships and children

In 1940, Oppenheimer married Katherine "Kitty" Posen, a former member of the Communist Party. The couple had two children, Toni and Peter. Oppenheimer's relationships with his family were complex, and he was often absent due to his work commitments.

## Mysticism

Oppenheimer was deeply interested in Eastern philosophy and mysticism, particularly Hinduism and Buddhism. He saw parallels between the principles of quantum mechanics and the concepts of Eastern mysticism, and he believed that both offered insights into the nature of reality.

# Manhattan Project

## Los Alamos

In 1943, Oppenheimer was appointed as the director of the Manhattan Project's secret research and development laboratory at Los Alamos, New Mexico. The laboratory was established to develop the atomic bomb, and Oppenheimer played a crucial role in its creation. He was responsible for assembling a team of scientists and engineers, including Enrico Fermi, Ernest Lawrence, and Richard Feynman.

## Bomb design

Oppenheimer's work at Los Alamos focused on the design of the atomic bomb. He was involved in the development of the implosion design, which used a sphere of fissile material surrounded by explosives. The implosion design was more efficient and effective than earlier designs, and it became the basis for the first atomic bomb.

## Trinity

On July 16, 1945, the first atomic bomb was detonated in the Trinity test at Alamogordo, New Mexico. Oppenheimer witnessed the test and was deeply moved by the experience. He later recalled that he was reminded of the Bhagavad Gita, a Hindu scripture, and the words "I am become Death, destroyer of worlds."

# Postwar activities

## Institute for Advanced Study

In 1947, Oppenheimer became the director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton University. The institute was a research center for theoretical physics, and Oppenheimer played a key role in shaping its research agenda. He was also a professor of theoretical physics at Princeton University.

## Atomic Energy Commission

In 1947, Oppenheimer was appointed as the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission's (AEC) General Advisory Committee. The committee was responsible for advising the AEC on matters related to nuclear energy and nuclear weapons. Oppenheimer played a crucial role in shaping the AEC's policies and was a strong advocate for international cooperation on nuclear issues.

## Panels and study groups

Oppenheimer was a member of various panels and study groups, including the National Science Foundation's advisory committee and the President's Science Advisory Committee. He was also a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the American Philosophical Society.

## Security hearing

In 1954, Oppenheimer was the subject of a security hearing by the Atomic Energy Commission. The hearing was triggered by allegations of disloyalty and communist sympathies, and Oppenheimer's security clearance was revoked. The hearing was widely seen as a witch-hunt, and Oppenheimer's reputation was severely damaged.

# Final years

## Enrico Fermi Award

In 1963, Oppenheimer was awarded the Enrico Fermi Award by the Atomic Energy Commission. The award recognized his contributions to nuclear energy and his leadership in the development of the atomic bomb.

# Death

Oppenheimer died on February 18, 1967, in Princeton, New Jersey, at the age of 62. He was cremated, and his ashes were scattered in the ocean off the coast of New Jersey.

# Legacy

Oppenheimer's legacy is complex and multifaceted. He is remembered as a brilliant physicist and a leader in the development of the atomic bomb. He is also remembered for his advocacy of international cooperation on nuclear issues and his commitment to social and economic justice.

# Publications

Oppenheimer published numerous papers on physics and philosophy, including his famous paper "On the Quantum Theory of the Capture of Neutrons by Atomic Nuclei" (1935).

# Notes

This article is a summary of Oppenheimer's life and work. For a more detailed account, see the sources listed below.

2022 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles

The 2022 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles was the main event of the 135th edition of the Wimbledon Championships. The tournament took place at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club in London, United Kingdom, from June 27 to July 10, 2022. This was the first edition of the tournament since the COVID-19 pandemic, which saw the cancellation of the 2020 edition and a reduced capacity in 2021. The event saw a total of 128 players competing in a knockout format, with the top 32 players seeded according to their ATP rankings.

# Seeds
